Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan. Here, you transition from farmland to small tourist towns. There are no big city malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you want to go, you have to drive. Despite this, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "city" is encircled by water, with beautiful Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Wherever you go, you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood reflects the idea of a small town. Houses are not crowded together, nor are they cookie-cutter homes. They are older houses, some updated and remodeled, others are just old. Most houses have full basements visible from the street. Many houses in the neighborhood have old aluminum siding. Around my house, there are homes in every color imaginable. Most houses have yards, with trampolines and playsets. Some people have gardens and fences for their animals. The houses represent Middle America, with hardworking people striving to make a living while raising or having raised families. On any given day, you will see kids running up and down the streets, and people walking dogs, biking, or rollerblading. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn’t. You might see someone grilling outside and wave, or someone walking their dog from a few blocks away and smile warmly. The lawns are well-maintained. No leaves from autumn are piled up. Green grass is kept mowed and controlled. If there are plants and bushes, they are trimmed neatly. It’s not a neighborhood that impresses with its beauty, but one where you sense it’s a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful, and safe. While it looks average, it’s exceptional because it represents what people desire in the world—a safe place to end the day. Within walking distance, there’s the county sheriff’s department and jail, with the health department right next to it. The city recycling center is just down the road, providing services used by neighbors and city residents. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear announcers keeping score and calling player names. Our small town airport is next to it, and you can hear the rumble of small engine planes taking off and landing whether you’re outside or inside. You can walk to get ice cream from the local shop, and if you’re really into it, you can reach downtown from our neighborhood. My kids can ride their bikes to the park, which is only about 8 blocks away. It’s truly a great place to live.

The area where I reside can be described as a typical suburban neighborhood. In my particular neighborhood, the presence of the homeowner's association is quite evident. As you enter, you see well-maintained single-family homes, thanks to the homeowner's association. The front yards are quite similar, with a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and short driveways. Occasionally, you'll spot small trees as well. Each house has a two-car garage. As you drive through the neighborhood, you'll notice newly paved concrete. Despite being home to many different families, the roads are in excellent condition, with no potholes or similar issues. Most of the houses are single-story, but sometimes you'll see two-story ones. We don't have the typical mailbox setup you might expect for single-family homes. Instead of individual mailboxes in front of each house, there is a large cluster of mailboxes at the end of the street, similar to apartments. Everyone uses a key to access their specific mailbox, and there are two larger lockers for packages. This uniformity is also thanks to the HOA. My house is located on the outskirts of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburban. As a result, we have a lot of space for various activities. There are several community pools accessible to residents, all well-maintained and gated. Additionally, there are various walking trails for walking your dog or taking an evening stroll alone. You don't need to visit a park to get your exercise. The neighborhood is large enough for running around and getting plenty of exercise. Most of the community consists of retirees, making it a very safe area where everyone looks out for each other. We also have a small number of middle-aged and young professionals. Regarding the city, it is surprisingly large in terms of population but retains a small-town feel. We have most of the amenities you would expect and rely on. For example, we have one mall. It isn't huge, but it serves its purpose. For me, it takes about 15 minutes to drive to any significant location, but once there, I'm greeted with a variety of stores to choose from. We have everything from high-end grocery stores with organic food to bargain outlets with a limited selection and minimal staff to keep costs down. Overall, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and quite typical. We have many nice features like pools and walking trails. Although we're not next to any shopping areas, you can easily drive to any major chain store you like.

The first time I heard about my place was while listening to a podcast about missing people. It was somewhat surprising. Almost every apartment in the area rents for over a thousand dollars a month. I had never heard that story, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's the struggle. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but over the years, we've learned how to be frugal. You start to appreciate the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. As an adult, you sense a lot less. You might start smoking, or maybe you've just become used to the way things are. But the flea market always makes its presence felt. The scent of adulthood is dusty magazines piled on a closed piano. It embeds itself in the leather, staying even after washing. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. If you start from the far end, you can visit two charity thrift stores, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is crowded, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but you wouldn't hear it in the thrift stores. Regardless of how many people or cars pass by, the store remains silent. It's a pleasant place to lose an afternoon. Each year, more of these places emerge. Cars and people flood in. It's said to be a developing city. It hosts the headquarters of one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, yet it still shows growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone and everything is set on their own goals, and not much is expected from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people leave you be. It’s not like the South, where showing a bit of concern means you care. Here, you don't really pry into anyone's life. You can maintain your shell as long as you like, and the city will ebb and flow like waves on a beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something happening. In some ways, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more of a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In some way, I'm fortunate to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors, and they treat me kindly. I try to keep things clean and leave them food, and they reciprocate. I bring them mail, and they do the same for me. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a vast, impersonal modern sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors who make me feel like I haven't completely ruined my life.

I reside in a small Midwestern town just outside a major city's suburbs. My neighborhood, located on the town's east side, is considered the most economically disadvantaged area. Property values are low, with most homes rented or owned by low-income residents. However, it's neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly and will smile and greet me when I walk down the street. While crime rates are slightly higher than other parts of the town, they are still relatively low. In the past decade, there have been a few violent crimes within a few blocks of my home, including shootings and at least one homicide. Our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a bar last year. Fortunately, our family hasn't been directly affected by crime, except for the occasional item disappearing from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. Overall, the town I live in has been deeply impacted by the "opioid epidemic" affecting many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost to fentanyl overdoses. Luckily, there are numerous resources in my town to combat this issue, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, the town has many positives. My son's elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to teachers and support staff. Despite his special needs, he hasn't faced any bullying due to the school's incredibly positive atmosphere, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that organizes multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Since over 20% of the town's population lives below the poverty line, the elementary school offers free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. No child or family is treated as "less than" due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the town's appearance, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most improvements have occurred in the town center and west side, where shopping areas are located and most traffic passes. The east side, where I live, tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for my neighborhood. Overall, I enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, schools are excellent, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family's needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it's comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we can't imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture. It is located on a hill, surrounded by historically significant buildings. I live in a seven-story apartment building right across from the old live theater, and one block down the hill is a cool little arcade bar that attracts various people on warm summer nights. Often, especially on weekends in June and July, you will see lines of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park, which is quite large considering the part of town it is in. The park is encircled by concrete, with tall steps embedded in the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the heavy downpours in mid-winter often make it hard to stay warm. By setting their tents close together in the city center rather than out in the wild, they stay much warmer. They are also within a reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city isn't the beauty of its historic nature—the tall, proud buildings, the architecture that dots the hills rolling towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people haven't forgotten. Stories from those days are still passed from generation to generation, reaching newcomers like me. The people work hard, even though it is still considered one of the tougher neighborhoods in the entire city, to keep it clean. They still care about what happens in their city, on their block. They say if you're white, you shouldn't walk around Hilltop after dark. I truly believe this warning is a relic of the past, tinged with the bitter taste of social conditioning. Perhaps I am just dark enough not to be seen as entirely "white," or maybe Hilltop sees me as one of their own, someone who is equally aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are borne out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who are more likely to offer me a jacket than rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners stay open a few minutes later so I can charge my phone when I have nowhere to escape from the rain. It's a place where I've sat, believing myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete storefronts on the dreariest of nights, only to have someone stop, look me in the eye, hand me $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I moved to this neighborhood just as I was about to start eighth grade. Initially, it was hard for me to make friends, but I eventually became close to someone who lived two houses down from me and another person on my street. They no longer live here, but the memories remain. Most of the people who were here when I first moved in are still here. My neighborhood is quite similar to a typical American suburban area, with many two-story houses. On weekends or whenever it's warm outside, I hear kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I've never had any issues with anyone here. You're left alone unless you need help. I've ordered many packages online and never had one stolen from my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There's a park just a minute or two from my house, where I have many memories. I've played basketball, football, and baseball there with others from the neighborhood. I also have one of my worst memories there, getting elbowed in the nose while playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, I go to that park to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger and still enjoy swings and slides. Just thinking about going to the park excites them. The park now makes me nostalgic for various reasons. The neighborhood is very diverse, offering a wide variety of food nearby. Within a one-mile radius, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, many people use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for food delivery. The most popular places are fast food spots, which you can find near any suburban area, and there are plenty of pizza places too. The stores here have everything you need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. On the same street, there's a Walgreens, a CVS, and a popular Midwest grocery store, Jewel-Osco. Some stores are also diverse; there's an Indian-owned store for those interested in homemade or ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am fond of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing news stories about other people's troubles with neighbors makes me grateful for mine.

My neighborhood is close to the college I attend, which makes living there enjoyable for me. It's mostly apartment buildings, with a few restaurants and bars that are fun and reasonably priced. One bar was recently renamed, and it's a bit pricier, but the service and drinks are decent. Most people here are friendly, either college students or lower-income residents, as the apartments are affordable. There are many children around because an elementary school is within walking distance of my apartment. I don't know my neighbors, nor do I want to, as they smoke a lot of weed, so the building management placed an air freshener by their door, which my boyfriend and I found amusing. The surrounding buildings often look old but might have renovated interiors. Further down the street, there are new apartments, which I dislike because I know the construction is subpar. They're cheaply made, yet the rent is high, which seems like a scam, but being close to campus allows management to get away with it. There is a very cheap restaurant five minutes away, serving food on paper plates, mostly microwaved. Across from it is a gas station, rumored to be a bad place to work. However, thanks to city funding, the road was redone last summer, with a nice wide sidewalk and plenty of grass, making the area a bit nicer. My apartment building is surrounded by trees, though some have been cut down, leaving stumps, but there are still more trees here than further down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and another set of apartments. I live on 42nd Street, with 43rd Street behind, which isn't as nice. Its sidewalks are crumbling, and most buildings look shabby. There are many trees on that street, probably to hide the buildings' appearance. Most crime in the area occurs at an apartment complex on that street, but I can't solely blame them. Apartments across from me also have high crime rates and a transient population. Still, I like living here. It's affordable, with plenty of amenities nearby. I especially appreciate being within walking distance of the university and having two bus stops, making it easy to get to stores and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes located on a cul-de-sac. They are spaced out to resemble individual houses. The only difference is that each one is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, though not all, is friends with each other. Some evenings, we gather at the end of an undetermined driveway to chat while the neighborhood's small children play with toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's refreshing in this modern world filled with technology. It's like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees, with blue skies and white clouds above. The only downside? This season, we have been experiencing tornado warnings, and for the first time last night, we actually heard the tornado sirens, so we had to seek shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my smallest dog, along with my purse and some pillows. My big dog refused to enter the bathroom and stayed in the living room, nervously barking at the unusual situation. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail falling around. After the storm, the road was steaming from the temperature change. We went from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As I looked up at the clearing skies, the sun came out, and it began to rain. A double rainbow appeared. I rushed inside to grab my camera and quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were amazed, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour until some people finally returned home from wherever they had been during the thunderstorm. Then life resumed as usual, with moms and children outside as dinner cooked. This is such a friendly neighborhood for someone like me who recently moved from NH to NC. I adore the southern accent people have here. I have a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, like everyone else. Although the houses look the same on the outside, not all apartments are the same inside. Some are quite small, which doesn't make sense to me. I love to walk along the large field behind my home and wander down to a pond that isn't meant for swimming. I've seen deer, and in the morning, you can hear the giant bullfrog singing. It's a fantastic place to live just forty minutes outside of Charlotte. Each morning is greeted by the sound of roosters from the surrounding farms. It's like living in its own small village community. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm, and you can hear it braying in the evening, letting us know it's there. I feel lucky to have found this gem of a neighborhood.

Well, considering I've been here for about ten years, I think I can share what I know. Initially, I was quite sad when I first arrived in this neighborhood. Moving from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I have to admit, I cried because I missed and loved them. However, my parents wanted the best for my sister and me, so we relocated to a better place with improved housing and schools, and nothing was considered "ghetto" when we moved to our new neighborhood. Over the years, I got used to it and made some new friends and enemies at school. Throughout the years, I never really got to know my neighbors, except for Mr. Glen and his children, and Dennis, both living right next to us. They are such pleasant people that I can almost consider them family, and I truly appreciate them. I remember when my family and I attended Mr. Glen's wedding (they remarried), it was incredibly fun, and I look forward to experiencing something like that one day, building my wealth and giving my future wife a queen's life. When Mr. Glen's wife, Ms. Veda, tossed the little white garter from her leg, I caught it! Unfortunately, I didn't catch the bouquet! We danced the night away, and I really enjoyed spending time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven't seen her since, and I hope she's moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself feels like a maze, but now with a GPS, I can take more time to explore. I've ventured out to some extent, mostly when hanging out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We used to play a lot of video games and enjoy life to the fullest. Sometimes I'd go to the park to enjoy nature, which soothes my soul and brings me peace these days. I also bring some sticks I bought from Home Depot to practice my balance, and if possible, my wooden bokken sword too. I have fun doing what I love. There is also a basketball and tennis court, though I haven't played in a while, it's nice to have them in case I want to pick up those sports again. My dad raised my best friend and me on tennis with Mr. Graves, and we always had a great time. They worked us hard but it was always fun. I guess I've had many enjoyable moments in this neighborhood, and there are plenty of stories, but these stick out the most to me, and I believe the best is yet to come!

My community is a charming little town. While it doesn't stand out in South Carolina, it plays a significant role in agriculture. Johnston is proudly known as the Peach Capital of the World, a fact celebrated on the welcoming sign. The area is mainly farmland, dominated by peach orchards and cattle. Houses outside the main part of town are widely spaced, typically two-storied with either metal roofs to beat the summer heat or gray shingles. These homes are often set back from the road, allowing front fields for animals or crops. In the town's main area, there's a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where the town's only stores are located. There are three places for "fast food": Hong Kong, a small family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizzeria once operated but closed recently. There's a tiny family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug, known amusingly for its Cherry Coca-Cola. An expensive small grocery store, the Independent Grocers Alliance, or IGA, is the only one in town, but most people go to Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for major grocery shopping. The most popular store is Dollar General, offering a wide range of everyday items and bustling from opening to closing! A very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, is run by a well-known kind woman in the community. It's been in Johnston for years and even has two movers for delivery! Next to it is a small pet groomers, Clark's Cuts and Kennels, offering services like daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, and bathing. Both a doctor's and a veterinary practice are located away from the town's center; they are small but well-equipped to serve Johnston's residents. There's one elementary school, Johnston Elementary School. After fifth grade, students must attend middle and high school in the neighboring town. Technically, there are no parks, but a 2.5-acre recreational area is being developed to provide more family outing opportunities and attract visitors and potential residents. Admittedly, there's not much to do; no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hangout" spots, playgrounds for children, pet walking areas, or diverse restaurants. Nonetheless, it's a pleasant town, so small you could pass through without noticing!

I reside in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a street that connects two state highways, so there's a bit more traffic than I would prefer, but otherwise, it's a quiet neighborhood. Not many people move in or out, so I've become familiar with most of the residents. People mostly keep busy with yard work and daily chores. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. Our house is at the front corner of the street, so we see everyone coming and going all day and recognize the cars people drive. We tend to notice any unfamiliar vehicles. Some neighbors walk for exercise or to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes, which is expected. We are home a lot since we work from the house. Our household consists of four members: myself, my wife, and our two daughters, who are eleven and fourteen years old. So, I assume others are used to seeing us come and go. We enjoy playing outside, sometimes even in the rain. Occasionally, we grill on our back deck, and the barbecue smell is always pleasant. It seems there's always someone mowing the lawn here, and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March until October when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood has many trees, as it was originally a wooded area, providing lots of shade, but there are also many leaves in the fall. This means raking and burning leaves yearly. I enjoy the smell of burning leaves, which is a nice sign of fall’s arrival. Recently, we haven't had much winter to speak of, so it just feels like an extended fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door unless someone knocks, which is rare. I like working on my truck or other projects in the garage, and with the doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. It’s quite peaceful around here during holidays. On Thanksgiving, some neighborhood families have guests from out of town, and there are extra cars parked everywhere. It's similar during other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I enjoy living here. It would be perfect if it weren't a through street.

My neighborhood is right in the heart of the high desert, where there's just dirt everywhere. Unless someone has lived here, they might not understand the constant view of brown, and when you spot a lawn, it indicates someone is spending a lot on its care. Back in the 90s when I first moved here, the houses were very spread out. It's still mostly like that now, but there are many new additions. Honestly, this place is starting to look more like a city every day, though I suppose most places are changing this way. Generally, people are friendly, but like any city, there are good and bad parts. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly elderly folks, so I guess it's a nicer area. The stores here are mostly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you want something upscale, you have to travel further; I've never seen any Whole Foods or similar stores. The most common jobs in my city, though not officially recorded, seem to be in construction. I think that's because the city is still not very developed, and there's a lot of open space to build on. That worries me a bit because I like how things are now. I left a big city and don't want to go back. Speaking of construction, that's my full-time job—I install drywall and T-bars. What I love about my home is the variety of animals. People come to the high desert for various reasons, not least of which is the desert's stark beauty. The high desert climate and terrain have created challenging ecosystems that need protection and are home to diverse wildlife. Residents should take the time to learn about the non-human inhabitants to coexist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted well to the wildlife. I have three kids, all obsessed with lizards and desert bugs; as I write this, they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As for attractions, we have a few. Additionally, Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert. It can offer a unique experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enhance your visit with activities and fun the Victorville way. Visit nearby Wrightwood to see snow-covered mountains and take winter sports lessons to conclude your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's social and industrial development.

When describing my neighborhood, I believe my answer is somewhat unique. While others might be homeowners with individual lives, my situation is slightly different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus where I reside, and the people living in my dormitory as my community. I also regard the surrounding campus as part of my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this uniqueness, my neighborhood shares some similarities with more conventional ideas of a neighborhood. Like any typical neighborhood, mine has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by discussing the "houses" in my neighborhood. Before exploring them, it's best to clarify the types of houses found here. There are three types of housing in my vicinity: apartments, actual houses, and dormitory houses. First, in the apartments, there are usually 2-4 people per room, with about 4-6 rooms per floor. The most common buildings have two floors, so on average, about 20 people live in each building. Second, there are actual houses available for anyone affiliated with the school to rent, usually 2-4 bedroom setups often accommodating alumni. However, these houses are less efficient and are only sparsely distributed throughout the neighborhood. Finally, there are typical dorm rooms housing hundreds of students, usually with two people sharing a room. This is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered, let's move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity, which is reflected in my neighborhood's makeup. People from all cultures and ages live here. Most of the professional staff reside in the neighborhood's houses, while new students stay in dormitory-style housing, and older students live in apartment-style housing. It’s hard to do justice to the people just by talking about them, so let's move on to the stores and parks. My school is essentially its own self-contained neighborhood, with plenty of stores and a single park. The stores offer a mix of dining options found in any neighborhood and the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. Therefore, anything needed can be found within my neighborhood! Additionally, the park serves as a playground for the diverse people here and is kept clean and safe by all neighborhood members!

There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to slope downward, and my house is right at the top of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "workout hill" because many joggers like to run up it for their daily exercise. Since there are no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road is pitted in some places, making driving a bit hazardous. Some of the telephone and electric wires around the block look tattered. Our area experiences a lot of rain and storms, so branches and debris often bring down power lines, and frequent repairs give them a patchwork appearance. Tall evergreen trees are everywhere, but people here dislike them as they block the ocean view. That's why many houses are built high on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that rise one after another to capture views of the bay. It's stunning around sunset when the water seems to light up from below and the sky turns orange. However, it's mostly cloudy, so you often see the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows wherever it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked in the driveway for a month, and when I went to use it, it was green and furry with moss. It took me three hours to scrape it all off. There aren't many children around where I live, even though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most people in my neighborhood are older, many retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them lounging on lawns or racing down the street. If you leave a door or window open, you risk them sneaking into your house. I once found one in my living room and had to shoo it out the front door. Rabbits run wild in the area. Some are quite large, and gardeners dislike them because they dig up plant roots and burrow into lawns. My cats love them, though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also have the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and occasionally a hawk or eagle flies by until the neighborhood crows chase it away. There aren't any stores nearby, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can clearly see the opposite shoreline even on most misty days.

If you are planning to visit Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, you won't have trouble finding it! Public transportation is very convenient and one of the most popular ways to get around in New York City. Bensonhurst is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you'll still feel like you're in New York City. During your visit, you'll notice various Asian stores everywhere. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurst has seen a significant influx of Asian residents. Because of this, as you walk, you'll see an Asian-owned shop on almost every block, with supermarkets and laundromats being the most common. These businesses are very popular among locals because the quality of food in the supermarkets is excellent, the prices are much cheaper, and importantly, it's very convenient. Near me, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk of each other. This adds to the convenience of grocery shopping. However, I'm not saying Bensonhurst is solely populated by Asian residents. It is quite diverse, with immigrants and their first and second-generation American children living here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the area are Asian-owned. Besides these Asian businesses, there's also a recently renovated park nearby, which features about ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for children, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy in the summer. Being in New York City, the parks are, of course, very diverse. You'll see all kinds of diversity here, playing and getting along well. In this neighborhood, there aren't many large corporate buildings. The buildings you find are for co-op living or condominium apartments. Most of the living spaces here are two-family houses. Most people are quite friendly, but it can be very noisy. Every day, you'll hear cars blasting music as they pass by, or revving their engines, waking you up in the morning. If you plan to visit at night, be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people can be unpredictable. You might encounter people who cause trouble for no reason, bullies, and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past through physical assault, but that was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package theft. Although common, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Lastly, although New York City has fines for not cleaning up after dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you'll see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station or supermarket. My biggest annoyance is dog waste on the ground everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing to understand about Portland, Oregon, is the meaning of "weird." The unofficial city slogan, displayed on a building that doubles as a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club, is "Keep Portland Weird." For some, it is a call to remember the Portland of the '90s and early 2000s, a lesser-known and less expensive Portland that fostered creative and unique subcultures. For others, it is an invitation—come to Portland, where being called weird is now a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the continuous construction of condos to house them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it means accepting the unconventional. It doesn't mean we lack modern conveniences and struggles. Like the rest of the nation, we buy most of our goods from China. There are countless ways to be weird, or not normal, but Portland also has plenty of normalcy. Portland has yoga, hipsters, and business professionals. Maybe weirdness means we take all of this a bit less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many around Portland, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. Free boxes, typically cardboard boxes with items someone is giving away, can also be plastic bags or containers. They often hold something magical, a perfect treasure for the passerby, surprisingly often. Free boxes usually contain clothes and books but can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about for me, but I am just one type of weird among thousands. Some people around me would never consider picking their clothes from a box on the sidewalk. Those folks go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real goats) or attend Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love a variety of things. It's full of people who chase our dreams or dream about chasing them while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug issues often stem from mental health problems, and the constant rain and dreary clouds throughout much of the year seem to contribute. Portland also faces a homelessness issue, for which no one seems to have a solution. The homeless are drawn to Portland for its social services, better than in most parts of the country, but still insufficient, as is the case nationwide. The non-homeless population oscillates between care and resentment. In this, we are not weird at all.

The mountains are a constant presence. In the north, they witness the sun's journey each dawn and dusk. Whether I forget them or am too busy with work and life to notice, they remain firm, untouched by life's troubles. On days of stress and tension, they insist on being seen, and when I look to them, they offer solace to my anxious soul, granting me strength to carry on, day by day. I first moved here for my undergraduate studies, and the mountains north of campus were what drew me in initially. The university boasts its own breathtaking sights in buildings, ponds, and trees, which have their place in my heart, but the mountains truly hold the crown. The town is beautiful in its own right. Many cafés have been the backdrop for countless hours of caffeine-driven study. You can walk or take a bus a bit further to the downtown area, enveloped by the antique feel of faded bricks lining restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town reveals as much hustle and energy as its urban neighbor. Yet, this bustle doesn't stretch far, as you can retreat back to the serene town by the library. This blend of atmospheres gives the city a wondrous vibe, inviting exploration. It makes it easy to create cherished memories, each tied to a part of town. Whether it's strolling past rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or rushing through the busy downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater with university-provided tickets. Alas, it's also home to many harsh memories, as all places inevitably are. The ponds, particularly, serve as a place for reflection and for crying sessions at two in the morning during an existential crisis, which I'm more familiar with. Watching turtles, ducks, and insects live their lives, each with a role, I couldn't help but question my purpose as I grappled with life's mystery. So, I walked past the pond, past the park and suburban houses, until I reached a main street. Then, the sun cast its brilliant rays over the palm trees, painting the sky, and as I looked at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they always had been. The sturdy mountains touched the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, silently stirring perseverance within me.

At first glance, you might overlook this area, as it lies behind a shopping strip in a residential zone—not a place one typically expects to find homes. Most people wouldn't choose to live there. However, if you venture behind the old, deserted Whole Foods and the hotels that see guests mostly during summer family reunions, you'll discover a lively community. On these streets, there are several apartment complexes, carefully arranged like Russian nesting dolls meticulously set in a line. The first apartments you encounter have been in the news for unsavory dealings, so we won’t dwell on those—appearances can be deceiving. Yet, the complexes beside them hold a world unknown to almost anyone living nearby. Opposite these complexes is a community college's quiet satellite campus, where students arrive with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 AM to start their day. The gates creak open to let them in one by one, while commuters grumble about the traffic delays on busy days. The road intersects with another residential street, featuring a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those recovering from broken bones. The center is adorned with cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan stirring the warm summer air. Children run and tumble in the park's grass, while bees hover lazily among the roadside flowers. Retirees walk their dogs along the path, frowning at skateboarders and nodding at the girls gossiping by the playground. Next to the park in the strip mall is a sushi place with affordable food that never seems too busy, a swim supply store, and a nail salon. You could fill your pool, get a manicure, and enjoy hibachi chicken all in one spot—the beauty of a strip mall. There's also a DIY frozen yogurt shop, often visited by teens clutching their cold cups while doing stunts on skateboards and vaping, thinking it's the coolest. This neighborhood is a slice of Americana—a historical corner in the sleepy South where little ever changes, not even time.

My neighborhood is fascinating. Most of the houses are single-family, but a few have been divided into two while still being connected, if that makes sense. My home has a small yard in front and a small driveway on the left. Like most others, it reminds you of a time not long ago when living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now it is fading. Yet, my neighborhood and many others still exist, calling out to us and visitors that the dream is still alive, and we hold onto it as best as we can. People aren't as optimistic as before, and the upkeep of the small yards isn't what it used to be, but there are still a couple of cars in every driveway, and the youth still play as if the world around them were their entire existence. The public school that has stood for nearly 90 years still stands, seeming to conjure a future for today's youth while stirring nostalgia in older residents. Churches are few and mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still bustling. All the homes look different but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a large Yemeni family, possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, and the kids often play football, only stopping for cars to pass. Most people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and can share stories of a past when everyone knew each other. There was a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, kids stopped wanting to be the Karate Kid, so now it's a pharmacy because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There's also a small movie theater that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from crowds by the youth's disdain for its lack of new releases, but favored by the elders, who think it's a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids, of course. There is a single expressway passing through my town, though the exit and entrance are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition for an exit for our town. The youth supported it, but the elders refused. They believed that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, and eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new high school, and we are trying to decide on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is very diverse. Residential areas are scattered seemingly at random among commercial areas, which host a variety of businesses. Some of these businesses consist of offices, while others are various shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There is no shortage of new restaurants to try or shops to visit. Some stores are large, well-known brands owned by big corporations, while small boutiques are also becoming increasingly popular. These are not only in malls but also line the streets, which are often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and peaceful, if not for the many attractions nearby. There are also a few parks nearby, and I have noticed that people frequently visit these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, there's actually a significant amount of diversity within my neighborhood. In a small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a group of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Beyond my neighborhood, there are many more people of different races and backgrounds, although they sometimes form their own small communities within the city. We have areas known as Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, even just a few miles can be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes take two hours due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere. While some points of interest are inevitably close by, the city is vast, and people generally do not prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be quite difficult to find parking spots almost anywhere. Ironically, there has been a lot of construction in recent years as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed at the prospect of even more people moving in and even more vehicles on the roads. However, there are many different types of houses in my city. Not everyone lives or wants to live in a large apartment building. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes, as well as smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even within my immediate neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of various ages, and to be honest, I am not familiar with most of my neighbors. It is not really a close-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all around my age.

As we drove past the expansive corn fields on the horizon, she asked, "Where is everything?" "This is it!" I replied, aware that she would be surprised by the vast, open landscape. Coming from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her house, she had never seen such wide open spaces. Struck by the endless corn fields, I shared with her my experiences growing up in rural Ohio. In that moment, she finally understood who I am and where I came from. Traveling down a two-lane country road, you come upon a water-filled quarry. Just beyond lies the small community where I reside. The houses are mainly built of brick and stucco. Each home has at least half an acre of land, which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During spring, the annually planted flowers flourish alongside the trees that change with each season in the Midwest. The driveways are lined with luxury Mercedes Benz cars that gleam in the midday sun after a thorough car wash. Continuing toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a welcoming smile. He often spends the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over the humming of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood finds him amusing, but he is a sincere and remarkable person with a unique history. As he has aged, he's lost some of his sharpness. In his past, he was a doctor and often blends into the grass with his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you reach my home. In the side yard, geese abound, chased by our Terrier. At the back, there's a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear the sounds of bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across a handmade wooden bridge lies an untouched oasis with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent much of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (mostly chasing them), there was always something to do, and usually a neighborhood child was ready to be a friend. Winters in my small town can be brutally harsh, yet they're incredibly beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into a barren wilderness. The trees that once held vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers become bare bark skeletons. When blessed with snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is adorned with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. As kids, my sister and I often fought, and in winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We'd build massive igloo-like forts to store our 'arsenal,' usually made from branches. In our own little wonderland, we played pretend, at a time when nothing else mattered. We were just carefree children.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food.
